entry.title: Unreal Engine - Level Editor
entry.content:
The General Sequence of Game Programming

  1. Prototyping
    • Verify that the game that you are making has value
    • Use “greyboxing” to quickly construct maps
      • Do not worry about the design, quickly construct map to test playing
      • Afterwards, you need to change the mesh template to actual assets. This process is called “meshing”.
  2. Pre-production
    • A rehearsal stage to bring the level of game to production level
    • This is stage that proves the entire ‘workflow’ of the game.
  3. Production
    • Finish the last bits for official deployment

Making simple levels

  • Look for Engine Contents
  • Click on BasicShapes folder
  • Drag the Cube static mesh

Play modes

  • Selected Viewport Mode
    • It is a play mode in viewport
    • Quickly play to check everything
  • Mobile Free View Mode
    • Simulate the play in a mobile environment (The preparation time is slow)
  • New Editor Screen (PIE) Mode
    • Play in a new screen (The screen resolution and ratio that you set are applied)
  • Simulated Mode
    • It is not a mode to play, it is a mode to observe the levels
      • You can see all the screen view that a player would see, but not be able to perform any game related functions
    • Use mouse and keyboard to look around the level freely
      • Conveniently place a particle effect or physical objects

Making levels using brush

Brush is a tool provided by unreal for greyboxing

  • Do not need to use external DCC and just use internal unreal editor tool to make mesh
  • Using ‘brush’ is not a common method to use
    • ‘Static mesh’ is commonly used
  • However, brush is very convenient to use, so use it when you need it
    • Used to make the entire outline and it is replaced with static mesh afterwards
    • Early stage prototyping for test usage
    • It is also usable for final mesh

entry.title: Computer Network - The Network Core
entry.content:
1️⃣ Packet Switching

  • Messages: Anything the application designer wants which are exchanged by end systems.
    • May contain data such as an e-mail message, a JPEG image, or an MP3 audio file.
  • Packets: A format which a long messages are broken down to.
  • Packet switches: A tool that packet travels.
    • There are two predominant types of packet switches: routers and link-layer switches
    • Packets are transmitted over each communication link at a rate equal to full transmission rate of link.
    • e.g. Source system or a packet switch is sending a packet of L bits over a link with transmission rate R bit/sec -> packet is transmitted at L/R seconds

Store-and-Forward Transmission

  • Store-and-forward transmission: The packet switch must receive the entire packet before it can begin to transmit the first bit of the packet onto the outbound link.
    • To explore in more detail, consider a simple network consisting of two end systems connected by a single router, as shown below. A router will typically have many incident links, since its job is to switch an incoming packet onto an ongoing link; in this simple example, the router has the rather simple task of transferring a packet from one (input) link to the only other attached link. In this example, the source has three packets, each consisting of L bits, to send to the destination. At the snapshot of the time shown below, the source has transmitted some of packet 1, and the front of packet 1 has already arrived at the router. Because the router employs store-and-forwarding, at this instant of time, the router cannot transmit the bits it has received; instead it must first buffer the packet’s bits. Only after the router has received all of the packet’s bits can it begin to transmit the packet onto the outbound link. To gain some insight into store-and-forward transmission, let’s now calculate the amount of time that elapses from when the source begins to send the packet until the destination has received the entire packet. The source begins to transmit at time 0; at time L/R seconds, the source has transmitted the entire packet, and the entire packet has been received and stored at the router. At time L/R seconds, since the router has just received and stored at the router. At time L/R seconds, since the router has just received the entire packet, it can begin to transmit the packet onto the outbound link towards the destination; at time 2L/R, the router has transmitted the entire packet, and the entire packet has been received by the destination. Thus, the total delay is 2L/R.

Let’s now consider the general case of sending one packet from source to destination over a path consisting of N links each of rate R (thus, there are N-1 routers between source and destination). Applying the same logic as above, we see that end-to-end delay is:

Queuing Delays and Packet Loss

  • Output buffer(a.k.a. output queue): Stores packets that the router is about to send into that link.
  • Queuing delays: Variable and depend on the level of congestion in the network.
  • Packet loss: The arriving packet or one of already-queued packets will be dropped since the buffer is already completely full.

Forwarding Tables and Routing Protocols

Forwarding table: Maps destination addresses to that router’s outbound links. Routing protocols: Used to automatically set the forwarding tables.

2️⃣ Circuit Switching

There are 2 fundamental approaches to moving data through a network of links and switches: circuit switching and packet switching.

Tip❗️

Circuit-switched network Packet-switched network
Resources needed along a path to provide communication between the end systems are reserved for commuication between the end systems Resources needed along a path to provide communication between the end systems are not reserved for commuication between the end systems

End-to-end connection: The network must first reserve one circuit on each of two links.

Multiplexing in Circuit-Switched Networks

A circuit in a link is implemented with either frequency-division multiplexing(FDM) or time-division multiplexing(TDM).

  • Frequency-division multiplexing(FDM): The frequency spectrum of a link is divided up among the connections established across the link.
  • Time-division multiplexing(TDM): Time is divided of fixed duration and each frame is divided into a fixed number of time slots.
  • bandwidth: The width of the frequency band.

  • silent period: A period of silent in circuit switching when network resources are allocated to the connection but are not used.

3️⃣ A Network of Networks

Network Structure 1

Interconnects all of the access ISPs with a single global transit ISP.

  • Customer: The access ISP
  • Provider: The global transit ISP

Network Structure 2

Two-tier hierarchy with global transit providers residing at the top tier and access ISPs at the bottom tier.

  • Regional ISP: The access ISPs in the region connect.
  • Tier-1 ISPs: Similar to (imaginary) global transit ISP.
    • e.g. Level 3 Communications, AT&T, Sprint, and NTT.

Tip ❗️

There is a customer-provider relationship at each level of the hierarchy. The tier-1 ISPs do not pay anyone as they are at the top of the hierarchy.

Network Structure 3

Multi-tier hierarchy, which is still only a crude approximation of today’s Internet.

  • Points of Presence(PoPs): A group of one or more routers in the provider’s network where customer ISPs can connect into the provider ISP.
  • Multi-home Connect two or more provider ISPs.
  • Peer: A pair of nearby ISPs at the same level of hierarchy, directly connecting their networks together so that all traffic between them passes over the direct connection to reduce the cost.
  • Internet ExchangePoint(IXP): A meeting point where multiple ISPs can peer together.

Network Structure 4

Ecosystem consisting of access ISPs, regional ISPs, tier-1 ISPs, PoPs, multi-homing, peering, and IXPs

Network Structure 5

Builds on top of Network Structure 4 by adding content-provider networks

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Big Data - MapReduce
entry.content:
Large Scale Computing for Data Mining

  • Process a lot of data to produce other data
  • Requirements
    • CPU, Memory, HDD, …
    • Multiple machine

Cluster Architecture

Fat-tree Architecture

  • Mining big data requires large-scale computing whose key component is parallel programming

Basic Operation: MapReduce

  • Created by Google (Jeffry Dean and Sanjay Chemawat) in 2004
  • Inspired from LISP
    • Map
      • Applies the given function to each element of the set
      • (map ‘length’(() (a) (a b) (a b c)) => (0 1 2 3)
    • Reduce
      • (reduce #’+’(1 2 3 4 5)) => 15

MapReduce is also Framework

  • Apache Hadoop MapReduce, Amazon Elastic MapReduce
  • Framework for parallel computing
    • Parallelization
    • Data distribution
    • Load balancing
    • Fault tolerance
  • Programmers get simple API
  • Allows one to process hug amount of data on thousands of processors

MapReduce as Programming Model

  • Sample problem
    • Find top 10URLs by access frequency by analyzing log files from web server(s)
  • The problem can be converted as WordCount
    • Counting words in a huge text document

WordCount

  • Assume that a file is too large for memory, but all <word, count> pairs fit in memory
    1. load a part of the file - Map
    2. count word - Map
    3. merge - Reduce
  • Each sub-task can be run in parallel
    • Reduce not only the resource usage, but execution time

Generalize Formally

  • Input: a set of key-value pairs
  • 2 methods:
    • Map(k, v) -> <k’, v’>*
    • Reduce( k’, <v’>* ) -> <k’, v’’>*

MapReduce: A Logical Diagram

MapReduce: Environment

MapReduce environment takes care of the following:

  • Partitioning the input data
  • Scheduling the program’s execution across a set of machines
  • Performing the group by key step
  • Handling machine failures
  • Managing required inter-machine communication

MapReduce: A Physical Diagram

Problems Suited for MapReduce

Host Size Example

  • Suppose we have a large web corpus
  • Look at the metadata file
    • lines of the form: URL, size, date, …
  • For each host, find the total of number of bytes
    • sum of the page sizes for all URLs from the particular host

Language Model Example

  • Statistical machine translation:
    • need to count number of times every 5-word sequence occurs in a large corpus of documents
  • Very easy with MapReduce:
    • Map: extract(5-word sequence, count) from document
    • Reduce: combine the counts

Join By MapReduce Example

  • Compute the natural (a.k.a. inner) join
  • R and S are each stored in files
  • Tuples are pairs (a,b) or (b,c)

  • Use a hash function h from B-values to 1…k
  • A Map process turns:
    • Each input tuple R(a,b) into key-value pair (b,(a,R))
    • Each input tuple S(b,c) into (b,(c,S))
  • Map processes send each key-value pair with key b to Reduce process h(b)
    • Hadoop does this automatically; just tell it what k is.
  • Each Reduce process matches all the pairs (b,(a,R)) with all (b,(c,S)) and outputs (a,b,c,).

Cost Measures for Algorithms

  • In MapReduce we quantify the cost of an algorithm using
    • Communication cost = total I/O of all processes
    • Elapsed communication cost = max of I/O along any path
    • (Elapsed) computation cost analogous, but count only running time of processes

Note that big-O notation is not the most useful, because adding more machine is always an option.

What Cost Measures Mean

  • Either the I/O (communication) or processing (computation) cost dominates
    • Ignore one or the other
  • Total cost tells what you pay in rent from your friendly neighborhood cloud
  • Elapsed cost is wall-clock time using parallelism

Design MapReduce Framework

Using MapReduce Framework

  • Programmer specifies: Map and Reduce and input files
  • Workflow:
    • Read inputs as a set of key-value-pairs
    • Map transforms input kv-pairs into a new set of k’v’-pairs
    • Sorts & Shuffles the k’v’-pairs to output nodes
    • All k’v’-pairs with a given k’ are sent to the same reduce
    • Reduce processes all k’v’-pairs grouped by key into new k’‘v’‘-pairs
    • Write the resulting pairs to files
  • All phases are distributed with many tasks doing the work

Data Flow

  • Input and final output are stored on a distributed file system(DFS):
    • Scheduler tries to schedule map tasks “close” to physical storage location of input data

Reference

  • Mining of Massive Datasets by Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman
  • Introduction to Big Data Lecture by Daejin Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Spring Boot - Injecting Data using Implemented Service

link.title: Spring Boot - Injecting Data using Implemented Service

entry.content:
I needed to inject some data that are in .csv format when starting Spring Boot using the service. I know that one of the options that I had was CommandLineRunner. However, I wanted to make my code clean.

CommandLineRunner Example

@EnableJpaAuditing
@SpringBootApplication
public class SpringApplication {
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(SpringApplication.class, args);
    }
    
    @Bean
    CommandLineRunner runner(ExampleService service) {
        return args -> {
            service.save("example");
        }
    }
}

I found another choice which was using ApplicationRunner. I chose this method because I was able to separate the specific codes that I need for inserting data. Also, I personally think that this way of structuring code is cleaner.

ApplicationRunner Example

@Component
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class InitialDataInsert implements ApplicationRunner {
    
    private final ExampleService service;
    
    public void insertData() {
        service.save("example");
    }
    
    @Override
    public void run(ApplicationArguments args) throw Exception {
        insertData();
    }
}

Reference

  • Application Runner in Spring Document

entry.title: Unreal Engine - Level Editor
entry.content:
Basic Terms

  • Unreal Editor: Development environment for Unreal engine.
  • Level Editor: An interface used for the design and construction of game levels and environments.
  • Level: Made up of a collection of static meshes, volumes, lights, blueprints, and more all working together to bring the desired experience to a player.
  • Asset: A piece of content for an Unreal project and can be thought of as a UObject serialized to a file.
  • Actor: Object in level such as a camera, static mesh, or player start location.

Default Interface

Coordinates

The coordinates follow left hand rule as you may have learned in high school physics class.

  • thumb: Points upward and represents the z-coordinate.
  • index finger: Points towards and represents the y-coordinate.
  • middle finger: Points to the right and represents the x-coordinate.

Camera control in view port

Move the camera around using these keys:

  • right click + w/s: move forward/backward
  • right click + a/d: move left/right
  • right click + q/e: move upward/downward

  • right click + z/c: zoom out/in

  • left click + drag: rotate left/right, move forward/backward horizontally
  • right click + drag: rotate left/right/upwards/downwards

  • wheel click + drag: move left/right horizontally, move upwards/downwards in perpendicular

  • left click + option/alt + drag: move around centering a pivot
  • right click + option/alt + drag: move towards/away from a pivot

  • wheel click + option/alt + drag: move left/right horizontally and forward/backward in perpendicular

  • select an object + f: focus the object

entry.title: Big Data - Data Mining Research
entry.content:
Introduction to Data Mining

What is Data Mining(DM)?

  • data mining: Extraction of interesting(non-trivial, implicit, previously unknown and potentially useful) pattern or knowledge from huge amount of data.
    • aka. Knowledge Extraction, Data Analysis, Data Science Information Harvesting, Business Intelligence, Predictive Analysis, etc.

KDD Process

Key Components in Data Mining

  • Data & Datatype
    • Database Data (extended-relational, object-oriented, heterogeneous, legacy), Data Warehouse, Transactional Data, Stream, Spatio-temporal, Time-series, Sequence, Text and Web, Multi-media, Graphs & Social and Information Networks
  • Data Mining Functions
    • Characterization, Discrimination, Association, Classification, Clustering, Trend/Deviation, Outlier Analysis, etc.
    • Descriptive vs Predictive Data Mining
    • Multiple/Integrated Functions and Mining at Multiple Levels
  • Techniques Utilized
    • Data-intensive, Machine Learning, Statistics, Pattern Recognition, Visualization, High-performance, etc.
  • Applications Adapted
    • Retail, Telecommunication, Banking, Fraud Analysis, Bio-data Mining, Stock Market Analysis, Health Care, etc.

DM Component: Data & Datatype

  • Database-oriented datasets and applications
    • Relational database, data warehouse, transactional database
  • Advanced Datasets and advanced applications
    • Data streams and sensor data
    • Time-series data, temporal data, sequence data (including bio-sequences)
    • Structure data, graphs, social networks and multi-linked data
    • Spatial data and spatio-temporal data
    • Multimedia database
    • Text databases
    • The World-Wide Web
  • Generalization
    • Multidimensional concept description: Characterization and discrimination
  • Association and Correlation Analysis
    • Frequent patterns or frequent item sets
    • How to mine such patterns and rules efficiently in large datasets?
    • How to use such pattern for classification, clustering, and other applications?
  • Classification
    • Construct models based on some training examples
    • Describe and distinguish classes or concepts for future prediction
      • e.g. Classify countries based on climate, or classify cars based on gas mileage
    • Predict some unknown class labels
  • Cluster Analysis
    • Unsupervised learning
    • Group data to form new categories
    • Principle: Maximizing intra-class similarity & minimizing inter-class similarity
  • Outlier Analysis
    • Outlier: A data object that does not comply with the general behavior of the data
    • Noise or exception
    • Useful in fraud detection, rare events analysis

DM Component: Techniques to be used

DM Component: Applications adapted

  • Web Analysis
    • e.g. from web page classification, clustering to PageRank algorithms
  • Collaborative analysis & recommender system
  • Basket data analysis to targeted marketing
  • Biological and medical data analysis: classification, cluster analysis, biological sequence analysis, biological sequence analysis, biological network analysis
  • Social networks
  • Journalism
  • Culture & Society

Diverse Issues in DM

  • Mining Methodology
    • Mining various and new kinds of knowledge
    • Mining knowledge in multidimensional space
    • Boosting the power of discovery in a networked environment
    • Handling noise, uncertainty, and incompleteness of data
    • Pattern evaluation and pattern- or constraint-guided mining
  • User Interaction
    • Interactive mining
    • Incorporation of background knowledge
    • Presentation and visualization of data mining results
  • Efficiency and Scalability
    • Efficiency and scalability of data mining algorithms
    • Parallel, distributed, stream, and incremental mining methods
    • Diversity of data types
  • Handling complex types of data
    • Mining dynamic, networked, and global data repositories
  • Data mining and society
    • Social impacts of data mining
    • Privacy-preserving data mining

Practical Tips for Starting Data Mining

Think the process first!

  • What is the exact problem?
  • What data do we need? Is the data available?
  • How can we represent the data?
  • What DM functions/techniques will you use?

1️⃣ step: Problem Definition

  • Define the problem as a scientific form
    • From a rough, uncertain, and undetailed problem to a clear and specific problem
  • Require domain knowledge as well as scientific problem-solving capability

2️⃣ step: Data Collection

  • Collecting data via
    • e.g. devices collection, web crawling, …

3️⃣ step: Data Representation

  • Transforming a high-dimensional raw data into problem-relevant data
  • Quantifying data with various techniques
    • Based on information theory, algorithm, and domain knowledge

Applying DM Functions/Techniques

  • Applying appropriate DM techniques
    • e.g. machine learning, statistical analysis, time-series analysis
    • multiple techniques can be applied together
  • Quantitative vs Qualitative -> Complementary

✅ Summary

Tip ❗️

One cycle is “ALWAYS” not enough! You need to go many (= hundreds or even thousands) cycles to conclude a claim.

Reference

  • Mining of Massive Datasets by Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman
  • Introduction to Big Data Lecture by Daejin Choi in Incheon National University
